title: 'We're not doing it': PM nixes GST call
text:
But there is no support among federal colleagues.

Liberal MP Tim Wilson, who chairs Parliament's economics committee, opposed the idea.

"I'm a big fan of stimulating the economy and you do that by cutting taxes, not raising taxes,'' he told Sky News.

Mr Wilson said the states needed to take more responsibility for the revenue they raised and "be accountable for it'', rather than relying on the Commonwealth to do the heavy lifting.

NSW Treasurer Dominic Perrottet rekindled discussion about the GST a fortnight ago when he called for a debate about the rate and base of the tax.

Already, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg and Finance Minister Mathias Cormann have ruled out looking at increasing the tax.

Shadow treasurer Jim Chalmers said the government could not be trusted.

"When wages are stagnant, and super and pensions are at risk, the Liberal Party now wants to jack up the GST as well,'' he said.

Advertisement

"When many multinational corporations are paying very little tax under this Morrison government, Liberals want pensioners and families to pay more.

"Josh Frydenberg is notorious for caving in to backbench pressure, which makes this latest idea from the Liberal fringe a serious threat to the household budgets of every Australian."

The last serious attempt to increase the GST was in late 2015 and early 2016 when Mr Morrison was Treasurer and Malcolm Turnbull Prime Minister.

They had Treasury model increases to the rate and base but after several months of contemplation, backed away.

In backing down, Mr Morrison said the sheer cost to the budget of compensating people on low incomes and welfare did not make the reform worth the effort.
description: A call by Liberal senator Dean Smith to broaden the base or rate of the GST has been knocked on the head by Scott Morrison.
